NSF Program: Security and Preparedness
Title: Collaborative Research: International Coercion, Debt Relief, and Land Transactions

This project will determine when governments transfer control over portions of their national territory to pay off loan debts to international creditors. The project will provide systematic evidence on the domestic and international conditions that influence the decisions of governments to exchange land for debt relief. The empirical analyses in the project will be based on a new dataset to be collected on all land transactions between countries related to debt relief. The results of this project will contribute to improving our understanding of when the international debt problems of countries can lead them to make territorial concessions to other countries.

The project will develop and test theory on the different debt relief strategies that governments can choose to adopt and why land transactions are sometimes selected instead of other available policies such as austerity or default. A new and more comprehensive dataset on land transactions for debt relief will be collected for the period 2000 to 2020. Statistical analyses of the new data set, employing simultaneous equations, will be conducted to test theoretical propositions. The results of the project will advance basic research on the management of international debt, the use of economic leverage by states to gain concession from states on security issues, and the dynamics of international negotiations over territorial concessions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project had two major outcomes. First, the project developed a theoretical framework for governments' responses to indebtedness in the context of international land transactions. Our theoretical approach examines the causes and consequences of land deals with two assumptions. First, we assume that the decision to sell/buy land is one policy option among many to deal with debt. For example, instead of using territory to generate revenue, a leader in a potential selling state can implement austerity or default on debt obligations to free up fiscal resources. Second, we assume that these various policy options produce different winners and losers. Leaders will want their supporters to "win" from these policy choices, or else risk losing power.

 

The second major outcome is data collection. This occurred in two stages. In the first stage, we verified existing international land transactions from the LandMatrix dataset. The Principal Investigators (PI), along with a group of research assistants, cross-referenced each observation against the resources listed in LandMatrix and conducted independent research to ensure the accuracy and currency of each observation. At least two coders examined each observation to minimize errors or discrepancies that could affect the quality and accuracy of the data. We verified 465 cases and added an additional 11 cases that were not originally included in LandMatrix.

 

In the second stage, we independently coded international land transactions for Africa. We identified a set of potential land deals (about 700). From these potential cases, we determined whether an actual transaction took place and recorded the corresponding characteristics (roughly 350). We examined two dimensions of the land transactions: information on the characteristics of the deal itself and whether the buyer is an entity directly related to a foreign government (such as a state-owned enterprise or a sovereign wealth fund) or merely a private firm. The verified data, along with the preliminary data collected from Africa, will be published in the spring of 2024 on the project’s Harvard Dataverse page (https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataset.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.7910/DVN/TINOBA).
